- Removed AuthorizationManagerMessageMatcherRegistry in favor of
enhancing MessageMatcherDelegatingAuthorizationManager.Builder
- Inlined MessageMatcherEntry
- Added pathMatcher supplier method to accomodate delaying PathMatcher setting
- Added AuthorizationChannelInterceptorTests
- Reverted EnableWebSecurity copyright change
- Updated JavaDoc to use EnableWebSocketSecurity', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/spring-security/commits/b90224a9c62fe39a14f9cb34839423d4356e6292'}]}

'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 5, 'created_at': '2022-03-24T08:28:12Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-11T20:41:32Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-11T20:41:32Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "Hello,

I was trying to extend the current pre authorization behavior to suit our needs. Basically I wanted to look at the request headers, if some conditions are met, execute a custom authorization code and grant access from that logic, otherwise delegate to default pre authorize authorization manager.

But this was very hard to understand and do.

In the documents, for customizing the @PreAuthorize authorization logic, it is said to be done like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159868373-717f9256-cae5-42bc-ad92-22be91be1d71.png)

But this only shows how to replicate the default behavior, not how to customize it.

As I set to do customize my logic and add a custom AuthorizationManager, I was faced with these challanges:

1. AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor doesn't have a factory function or constructor that just accepts an AuthorizationManager and can only be instantiated with a default authorization managers(Yes it has one that accepts an AuthorizationManager, but it also needs a pointcut, which I will come back later)
2. Since I saw that, I wanted to create a custom class that extended PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager. In here, I wanted to execute some logic or delegate to super in other cases. But I saw that PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager, or any other concrete implementation of AuthorizationManager, are marked as final and can't be extended to customize the logic and be provided to AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor.
3. Event if you write a custom AuthorizationManager that executes your logic or delegates to constructed PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager in other cases, you need to provide a Pointcut to pass to interceptor. Unfortunately, the utility class used to get the Pointcuts for @PreAuthorize annotation(AuthorizationMethodPointcuts) is package private and you can't easily create the pointcut that you need.

Because of that, I had to create a default AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor, get its Pointcut, than create my own custom interceptor with this pointcut and my custom delegating AuthorizationManger.

Here is the code that I had to write:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159869665-379325f2-ea9e-4636-b8c7-a0baa1c52e35.png)

And this is the custom AuthorizationManager:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159872621-2bd1983c-4b93-4aea-87e1-25dd5a561958.png)

The code is very small, but in order to get there, I had to fumble through a lot of source code.

There were a lot of pain points while trying to figure out how to do some basic thing.

Here our my suggestions:

1. Make the concrete implementations of AuthorizationManager non-final, so that we can extend them and customize it with our logic, or make them more composeable.
2. Add a builder or constructor to AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor to only get an AuthorizationManager to be used inside, and not bother with pointcuts and use the default one, as it is the case with factory function that takes a PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager.
3. Add a section on how to create your own AuthorizationManager and register it as default for one or more of the interceptors that come with @EnableMethodSecurity, ideally showing how to delegate to default managers.

I don't know if I over-complicated things with my limited knowledge of the new authorization architecture, but in other parts of the spring security, by just reading the source code and understanding the default behavior, I could extend or compose the existing classes with my own to suit my needs. But this was not that easy to do with the current authorization classes.

Thank you.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 1, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

2. Since I saw that, I wanted to create a custom class that extended PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager. In here, I wanted to execute some logic or delegate to super in other cases. But I saw that PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager, or any other concrete implementation of AuthorizationManager, are marked as final and can't be extended to customize the logic and be provided to AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor.
3. Event if you write a custom AuthorizationManager that executes your logic or delegates to constructed PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager in other cases, you need to provide a Pointcut to pass to interceptor. Unfortunately, the utility class used to get the Pointcuts for @PreAuthorize annotation(AuthorizationMethodPointcuts) is package private and you can't easily create the pointcut that you need.

'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 3, 'created_at': '2022-03-24T08:28:12Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-11T20:38:09Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "Hello,

I was trying to extend the current pre authorization behavior to suit our needs. Basically I wanted to look at the request headers, if some conditions are met, execute a custom authorization code and grant access from that logic, otherwise delegate to default pre authorize authorization manager.

But this was very hard to understand and do.

In the documents, for customizing the @PreAuthorize authorization logic, it is said to be done like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159868373-717f9256-cae5-42bc-ad92-22be91be1d71.png)

But this only shows how to replicate the default behavior, not how to customize it.

As I set to do customize my logic and add a custom AuthorizationManager, I was faced with these challanges:

1. AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor doesn't have a factory function or constructor that just accepts an AuthorizationManager and can only be instantiated with a default authorization managers(Yes it has one that accepts an AuthorizationManager, but it also needs a pointcut, which I will come back later)
2. Since I saw that, I wanted to create a custom class that extended PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager. In here, I wanted to execute some logic or delegate to super in other cases. But I saw that PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager, or any other concrete implementation of AuthorizationManager, are marked as final and can't be extended to customize the logic and be provided to AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor.
3. Event if you write a custom AuthorizationManager that executes your logic or delegates to constructed PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager in other cases, you need to provide a Pointcut to pass to interceptor. Unfortunately, the utility class used to get the Pointcuts for @PreAuthorize annotation(AuthorizationMethodPointcuts) is package private and you can't easily create the pointcut that you need.

Because of that, I had to create a default AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor, get its Pointcut, than create my own custom interceptor with this pointcut and my custom delegating AuthorizationManger.

Here is the code that I had to write:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159869665-379325f2-ea9e-4636-b8c7-a0baa1c52e35.png)

And this is the custom AuthorizationManager:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159872621-2bd1983c-4b93-4aea-87e1-25dd5a561958.png)

The code is very small, but in order to get there, I had to fumble through a lot of source code.

There were a lot of pain points while trying to figure out how to do some basic thing.

Here our my suggestions:

1. Make the concrete implementations of AuthorizationManager non-final, so that we can extend them and customize it with our logic, or make them more composeable.
2. Add a builder or constructor to AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor to only get an AuthorizationManager to be used inside, and not bother with pointcuts and use the default one, as it is the case with factory function that takes a PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager.
3. Add a section on how to create your own AuthorizationManager and register it as default for one or more of the interceptors that come with @EnableMethodSecurity, ideally showing how to delegate to default managers.

I don't know if I over-complicated things with my limited knowledge of the new authorization architecture, but in other parts of the spring security, by just reading the source code and understanding the default behavior, I could extend or compose the existing classes with my own to suit my needs. But this was not that easy to do with the current authorization classes.

Thank you.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 1, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1095543391', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024#issuecomment-1095543391', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024', 'id': 1095543391, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOADAMs85BTKpf', 'user': {'login': 'jzheaux', 'id': 3627351, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjM2MjczNTE=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3627351?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jzheaux', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-04-11T20:38:09Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-11T20:38:09Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': "Thanks, @fatihdogmus, I see my mistake. 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/issues/3100/events', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/issues/3100', 'id': 1184082034, 'node_id': 'I_kwDOBTyixM5Gk6hy', 'number': 3100, 'title': 'Observe instantaneous events', 'user': {'login': 'jonatan-ivanov', 'id': 3044070, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjMwNDQwNzA=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3044070?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jonatan-ivanov', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jonatan-ivanov', 'followers_url': and the community to review"}], 'state': 'open', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2022-03-28T22:52:19Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-01T13:18:10Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'MEMBER', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'This issue is for having open discussion and feedback about the ability of observing instantaneous events using the Observation API.
Right now, an Observation needs to be started and stopped and it also has a duration. There are use-cases where the event we are observing is instantaneous or we don't care about its duration.

One fictitious example could be a repair shop where we can measure each step of repairing something (with duration) but as tools used in a step can worn out, they need to be replaced during the process. This "replace-the-tool" even can be instantaneous and we probably want to record the fact that a tool got replaced during the process.

A more real-life scenario could be listening to security events like [these](https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-sleuth/blob/385aedbdff34b47117bc450bc6bf6a4e9f573089/spring-cloud-sleuth-instrumentation/src/main/java/org/springframework/cloud/sleuth/instrument/security/TracingSecurityContextChangedListener.java#L53-L71). This tracks through a scenario when a user can "authenticated", this authentication can be replaced (elevated) and the user can lose its "authenticated" status.
As an output we can log, count, and annotate spans with these events.

Another interesting scenario can be structured logging for security events. A common ask for security libraries (/cc @jzheaux) is logging out security events in a well-defined and structured format (CEF, LEEF). These events are by nature instantaneous, also multiple events (even multiple instances of the same event) can happen in a single call (request). Being able to observe instantaneous events would cover this use-case also, it would make it easy to extend the logging functionality with recording counters and/or annotating spans.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/issues/3100/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/issues/3100/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/issues/comments/1085890622', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/issues/3100#issuecomment-1085890622', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/issues/3100', 'id': 1085890622, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOBTyixM5AuWA-', 'user': {'login': 'jzheaux', 'id': 3627351, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjM2MjczNTE=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3627351?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jzheaux', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-04-01T13:18:10Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-01T13:18:10Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'body': "Other possible examples from the security space:

`SessionCreatedEvent` - It's valuable to know when sessions are created, how many were created over a span of time, if several were created from a given IP address, etc. Oftentimes, sessions are abandoned, so it's not ideal to wait for a session destroyed event to close the observation. There would likely be numerous orphaned timers. 

It's not yet clear to me that Micrometer is ideal for simplifying security audits. But if so, then we also don't want to wait until a session is destroyed to find out a session was created, from an incident response perspective.

`AccountLockedEvent` - This is a consequence of potentially disparate conditions and is not tied to any particular request. For example, a user has tried too many times with an incorrect password. Or, an admin locks the account manually. Or, when an application is listening on a background topic for security events, it makes a decision to lock several accounts to automatically guard against a discovered threat. 

Instead of needing to parse how many account locks happen across disparate timers of varying business cases, each of these applications can simply fire an `AccountLockedEvent` and Spring Security can record the event using Micrometer.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/issues/comments/1085890622/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

{'push_id': 9508458166, 'size': 18, 'distinct_size': 4, 'ref': 'refs/heads/exercises-module-four', 'head': '339174d29796a064adf7aeefa6cd0ece47721bfe', 'before': '506b19e45dd71c75a82664dbe28191e0b0241a91', 'commits': [{'sha': 'b1657d14f8ab7fd56ceadd82364e3158af4c77aa', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Updated Links', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/b1657d14f8ab7fd56ceadd82364e3158af4c77aa'}, {'sha': 'd65432d6b14a3a47616b278dc70b55d0d17cc494', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Update to Spring Boot 2.5.12', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/d65432d6b14a3a47616b278dc70b55d0d17cc494'}, {'sha': '2c0f8e6bcb8018e072be4a34b29fbec7942d1c80', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Update to Spring Authorization Server 0.2.3', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/2c0f8e6bcb8018e072be4a34b29fbec7942d1c80'}, {'sha': '679e86be1e4ec0a34855705deb2558cfbcd0dddf', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Update Authorization Server Configuration', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/679e86be1e4ec0a34855705deb2558cfbcd0dddf'}, {'sha': '1a9a21e0cee3b5de5a5594ed262f3a7305812abc', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': "Step One: Enable Auto-configuration

By default, Spring Boot with auto-configure Spring Security to protect
all endpoints. It will also create a user with a generated password.

So that you could better envision life without the auto-configuration,
this was manually shut off in the project.

In a real project, all that's necessary to get this behavior is to add
the spring-boot-starter-security dependency.", 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/1a9a21e0cee3b5de5a5594ed262f3a7305812abc'}, {'sha': '1dc850b17a6c431b4ae4b05892c196143aa550f5', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Two: In-memory Users

We can authenticate a REST API with an in-memory set of users. This
works for only the simplest of APIs, but is certainly handy to get us
started.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/1dc850b17a6c431b4ae4b05892c196143aa550f5'}, {'sha': 'aaee6db1da78369a0b68336a6bf92c2a668d54ae', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Three: A Spring Data-based UserDetailsService

A UserDetailsService is designed to be able to query any repository by
username, and Spring Data repositories are a great fit.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/aaee6db1da78369a0b68336a6bf92c2a668d54ae'}, {'sha': '4b26059d79e7da0ef4efe5f33ef02070b3f4a6ac', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Four: Accessing domain-specific information

Your controllers can now gain access to domain-specific information
via the @CurrentSecurityContext annotation.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/4b26059d79e7da0ef4efe5f33ef02070b3f4a6ac'}, {'sha': '0254cb72e15ab6b2e967a9ffb335afa433063556', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': "Step One: Enable and Use @PreAuthorize

By default, Spring Security ignores method-based security annotations.
To add this, we'll need the @EnableGlobalMethodSecurity annotation.

Spring Security supports filter- and method-based authorization.
The @PreAuthorize method annotation describes what authorities are needed
to invoke the given method.", 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/0254cb72e15ab6b2e967a9ffb335afa433063556'}, {'sha': '57ffc7d55afbc5830e30bb36ec734a50fc150aa5', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': "Step Two: Insecure Direct Object References

Just because a REST client has the primary key to an entity, it doesn't
mean that they are authorized to read it. You can use @PostAuthorize to
check whether the owner of the resource belongs to the logged in user.

If there is a circumstance when we can't filter by logged-in user at the
query level, we can use the @PostFilter annotation to do it at the
method level. Note that modifying @Query expression is preferred,
though, as it will scale much better.

Adding to a query's where clause is a nice, scalable way to filter
results down to only those owned by the user.

Note that @PostAuthorize is still needed, if you want to throw an 403
instead of a 404, since once you add the user to the query, it might
return no results at all.", 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/57ffc7d55afbc5830e30bb36ec734a50fc150aa5'}, {'sha': '07bca0ba38c3b96aadf439983063eb43912a12c8', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Three: Externalizing Authorization Expressions

Authorization expressions can get quite complex and tricky to maintain.
One simple way to extract the logic is to expose a bean and then refer
to that bean in the authorization expression.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/07bca0ba38c3b96aadf439983063eb43912a12c8'}, {'sha': '7aee51914e8df816fc92bc474291506122877f8b', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Four: Inferring Permissions from Roles

Often times, roles are an abstraction for a set of permissions. We can
leverage that at authentication time by deriving the appropriate
permissions from the set of roles.

By doing this at authentication time, it can simplify our authorization
expressions.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/7aee51914e8df816fc92bc474291506122877f8b'}, {'sha': '5f4f90f0b80af95c44dbb42d94cbbfc8236faa1e', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step One: Allowing CORS at an Endpoint

Adding the @CrossOrigin annotation to a Spring MVC mapping opens up
calling that method to any Origin.

Calling the `cors` method on the Spring Security DSL configures Spring
Security to allow the preflight request without the user first being
authenticated.

For HTTP Basic to work in a Single-Page Application, you need to
configure CORS to the cross-origin to send credentials. This should only
be done in a high-trust situation as this would allow malicious users to
induce the client application to send cookies and bypass CSRF
restrictions.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/5f4f90f0b80af95c44dbb42d94cbbfc8236faa1e'}, {'sha': 'd7432437b44198d584ac57ca545984d16f9b1f19', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Two: Allow CSRF Header

The CSRF Header needs to also be allowed through CORS.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/d7432437b44198d584ac57ca545984d16f9b1f19'}, {'sha': '5e7fb45ceb47001bb7299f00509ae6b8c463729b', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step One: Configure for Bearer Tokens

You can use the Spring Security DSL to declare that the REST API will
authenticate bearer tokens.

Also, when this is the case, CSRF is not required since bearer tokens
are not managed nor sent automatically by the browser, which simplifies
our CORS configuration.', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/5e7fb45ceb47001bb7299f00509ae6b8c463729b'}, {'sha': '00a16a5291c5bb41cd2fb6178e34ed8b465e5b60', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Two: Configure How Scopes Convert to Authorities

You can use JwtAuthenticationConverter to change how a Jwt gets turned
into an Authentication. Also, you can use JwtGrantedAuthoritiesConverter
to change how the Jwt is convertered into instances of GrantedAuthority.', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/00a16a5291c5bb41cd2fb6178e34ed8b465e5b60'}, {'sha': '47bb050ce890456a3326194fdc25dc88732d75ac', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': "Step Three: Customizing the Principal

Customizing the user principal with JWT is similar to what you did in
Module 1 when you customized it with HTTP Basic. Here, you introduce a
bridge object and then return an authentication that supports a custom
principal, which in this case is BearerTokenAuthentication.

Also observe the important difference between user authorities and
client authorities. In the custom JwtAuthenticationConverter, the
authorities are merged since we don't want a client to do something
that the user can't.", 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/47bb050ce890456a3326194fdc25dc88732d75ac'}, {'sha': '339174d29796a064adf7aeefa6cd0ece47721bfe', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': "Step Four: Programmatic Security

Spring Security encourages a declaration security authorization model.

However, at times it may be necessary to make an authorization decision
programmatically, like in this case when some information is withheld
if the authentication doesn't have the appropriate authority.

Note that there are declarative ways to achieve this, too. This commit
demonstrates Spring Security's flexibility.", 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/339174d29796a064adf7aeefa6cd0ece47721bfe'}]}

{'push_id': 9508458126, 'size': 8, 'distinct_size': 0, 'ref': 'refs/heads/exercises-module-one', 'head': '4b26059d79e7da0ef4efe5f33ef02070b3f4a6ac', 'before': 'b26b93b32acd795b20885fe2cb12ea8d418dc3ec', 'commits': [{'sha': 'b1657d14f8ab7fd56ceadd82364e3158af4c77aa', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Updated Links', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/b1657d14f8ab7fd56ceadd82364e3158af4c77aa'}, {'sha': 'd65432d6b14a3a47616b278dc70b55d0d17cc494', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Update to Spring Boot 2.5.12', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/d65432d6b14a3a47616b278dc70b55d0d17cc494'}, {'sha': '2c0f8e6bcb8018e072be4a34b29fbec7942d1c80', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Update to Spring Authorization Server 0.2.3', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/2c0f8e6bcb8018e072be4a34b29fbec7942d1c80'}, {'sha': '679e86be1e4ec0a34855705deb2558cfbcd0dddf', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Update Authorization Server Configuration', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/679e86be1e4ec0a34855705deb2558cfbcd0dddf'}, {'sha': '1a9a21e0cee3b5de5a5594ed262f3a7305812abc', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': "Step One: Enable Auto-configuration

By default, Spring Boot with auto-configure Spring Security to protect
all endpoints. It will also create a user with a generated password.

So that you could better envision life without the auto-configuration,
this was manually shut off in the project.

In a real project, all that's necessary to get this behavior is to add
the spring-boot-starter-security dependency.", 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/1a9a21e0cee3b5de5a5594ed262f3a7305812abc'}, {'sha': '1dc850b17a6c431b4ae4b05892c196143aa550f5', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Two: In-memory Users

We can authenticate a REST API with an in-memory set of users. This
works for only the simplest of APIs, but is certainly handy to get us
started.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/1dc850b17a6c431b4ae4b05892c196143aa550f5'}, {'sha': 'aaee6db1da78369a0b68336a6bf92c2a668d54ae', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Three: A Spring Data-based UserDetailsService

A UserDetailsService is designed to be able to query any repository by
username, and Spring Data repositories are a great fit.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/aaee6db1da78369a0b68336a6bf92c2a668d54ae'}, {'sha': '4b26059d79e7da0ef4efe5f33ef02070b3f4a6ac', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Four: Accessing domain-specific information

Your controllers can now gain access to domain-specific information
via the @CurrentSecurityContext annotation.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/4b26059d79e7da0ef4efe5f33ef02070b3f4a6ac'}]}

{'push_id': 9508458095, 'size': 12, 'distinct_size': 0, 'ref': 'refs/heads/exercises-module-two', 'head': '7aee51914e8df816fc92bc474291506122877f8b', 'before': '744acb9cb8bb4bada0d95d5d0a1ddc189558ea63', 'commits': [{'sha': 'b1657d14f8ab7fd56ceadd82364e3158af4c77aa', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Updated Links', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/b1657d14f8ab7fd56ceadd82364e3158af4c77aa'}, {'sha': 'd65432d6b14a3a47616b278dc70b55d0d17cc494', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Update to Spring Boot 2.5.12', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/d65432d6b14a3a47616b278dc70b55d0d17cc494'}, {'sha': '2c0f8e6bcb8018e072be4a34b29fbec7942d1c80', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Update to Spring Authorization Server 0.2.3', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/2c0f8e6bcb8018e072be4a34b29fbec7942d1c80'}, {'sha': '679e86be1e4ec0a34855705deb2558cfbcd0dddf', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Update Authorization Server Configuration', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/679e86be1e4ec0a34855705deb2558cfbcd0dddf'}, {'sha': '1a9a21e0cee3b5de5a5594ed262f3a7305812abc', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': "Step One: Enable Auto-configuration

all endpoints. It will also create a user with a generated password.

So that you could better envision life without the auto-configuration,
this was manually shut off in the project.

In a real project, all that's necessary to get this behavior is to add

works for only the simplest of APIs, but is certainly handy to get us
started.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/1dc850b17a6c431b4ae4b05892c196143aa550f5'}, {'sha': 'aaee6db1da78369a0b68336a6bf92c2a668d54ae', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Three: A Spring Data-based UserDetailsService

A UserDetailsService is designed to be able to query any repository by
username, and Spring Data repositories are a great fit.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/aaee6db1da78369a0b68336a6bf92c2a668d54ae'}, {'sha': '4b26059d79e7da0ef4efe5f33ef02070b3f4a6ac', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Four: Accessing domain-specific information

Your controllers can now gain access to domain-specific information
via the @CurrentSecurityContext annotation.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/4b26059d79e7da0ef4efe5f33ef02070b3f4a6ac'}, {'sha': '0254cb72e15ab6b2e967a9ffb335afa433063556', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': "Step One: Enable and Use @PreAuthorize

By default, Spring Security ignores method-based security annotations.
To add this, we'll need the @EnableGlobalMethodSecurity annotation.

Spring Security supports filter- and method-based authorization.
The @PreAuthorize method annotation describes what authorities are needed
to invoke the given method.", 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/0254cb72e15ab6b2e967a9ffb335afa433063556'}, {'sha': '57ffc7d55afbc5830e30bb36ec734a50fc150aa5', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': "Step Two: Insecure Direct Object References

Just because a REST client has the primary key to an entity, it doesn't
mean that they are authorized to read it. You can use @PostAuthorize to
check whether the owner of the resource belongs to the logged in user.

If there is a circumstance when we can't filter by logged-in user at the
query level, we can use the @PostFilter annotation to do it at the
method level. Note that modifying @Query expression is preferred,
though, as it will scale much better.

Adding to a query's where clause is a nice, scalable way to filter
results down to only those owned by the user.

Note that @PostAuthorize is still needed, if you want to throw an 403
instead of a 404, since once you add the user to the query, it might
return no results at all.", 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/57ffc7d55afbc5830e30bb36ec734a50fc150aa5'}, {'sha': '07bca0ba38c3b96aadf439983063eb43912a12c8', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Three: Externalizing Authorization Expressions

Authorization expressions can get quite complex and tricky to maintain.
One simple way to extract the logic is to expose a bean and then refer
to that bean in the authorization expression.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/07bca0ba38c3b96aadf439983063eb43912a12c8'}, {'sha': '7aee51914e8df816fc92bc474291506122877f8b', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Four: Inferring Permissions from Roles

Often times, roles are an abstraction for a set of permissions. We can
leverage that at authentication time by deriving the appropriate
permissions from the set of roles.

By doing this at authentication time, it can simplify our authorization
expressions.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/7aee51914e8df816fc92bc474291506122877f8b'}]}

Adding the @CrossOrigin annotation to a Spring MVC mapping opens up
calling that method to any Origin.

Calling the `cors` method on the Spring Security DSL configures Spring
Security to allow the preflight request without the user first being
authenticated.

For HTTP Basic to work in a Single-Page Application, you need to
configure CORS to the cross-origin to send credentials. This should only
be done in a high-trust situation as this would allow malicious users to
induce the client application to send cookies and bypass CSRF
restrictions.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/5f4f90f0b80af95c44dbb42d94cbbfc8236faa1e'}, {'sha': 'd7432437b44198d584ac57ca545984d16f9b1f19', 'author': {'email': 'josh.cummings@gmail.com', 'name': 'Josh Cummings'}, 'message': 'Step Two: Allow CSRF Header

The CSRF Header needs to also be allowed through CORS.', 'distinct': False, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/oreilly-spring-security-rest-apis/commits/d7432437b44198d584ac57ca545984d16f9b1f19'}]}

Update to Spring Boot 2.5.12 [#378](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security-oauth2-boot/issues/378) ', 'short_description_html': '

'2022-03-31T00:42:06Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '### Summary

The usual Spring MVC Security allows us to [reference beans in the web security expressions](https://docs.spring.io/spring-security/site/docs/5.2.0.RC1/reference/htmlsingle/#el-access-web-beans):

```
http
        .authorizeRequests()
                .antMatchers("/user/**").access("@webSecurity.check(authentication,request)")
                ...
```

Currently the reactive version doesn't offer an access method with a String for web expressions, only with a `ReaciveAuthorizationManager`.



### Actual Behavior

This is the API offered by `pathMatchers` 
```
.authorizeExchange()
                    .pathMatchers("").access( ReaciveAuthorizationManager ... )
```
### Expected Behavior

Possibility of configuring a security web expression:

```
http
        .authorizeExchange()
                .antMatchers("/user/**").access("@webSecurity.check(authentication,request)")
                ...
```

### Configuration

...

### Version

5.2.0.RC1

How is the `webSecurity` bean in your sample materially different from publishing a `ReactiveAuthorizationManager` implementation and using that? It seems like the logic in `webSecurity#check` would be nearly identical to a concrete `ReactiveAuthorizationManager` implementation.

Generally speaking, I don't see the appeal to using SpEL when it's simple to provide a concrete, unit-testable authorization implementation instead. Additionally, applications have tended over the years to embed an unhealthy amount of logic in their security SpEL expressions, so I'm hesitant to add a feature that encourages that practice.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1083871508/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'2022-03-31T00:05:26Z', 'closed_at': '2021-11-09T22:51:13Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Expected Behavior**

It would be great for `ReactiveRemoteJWKSource` to use a `WebClient` instance that respects the `http.proxy` system properties, as described in https://github.com/reactor/reactor-netty/issues/887 .

**Current Behavior**

`ReactiveRemoteJWKSource` creates a `WebClient` instance that ignores the `http.proxy` properties. 

**Context**

We have a resource server application  built with spring webflux. Our oAuth2 server is accessible only through a proxy . Our application is unable to reach the oauth2 server in order to validate tokens because requests to the oAuth2 server from our spring reactive application are not routed through the proxy.

I haven't managed to find a workaround yet, any suggestions welcome!

I wonder if the user could simply do `@authz.checkReactive(#root, 'ADMIN')` and then invoke `hasRole('ADMIN')` from within the `authz` bean.

Personally, I'm not a huge fan of embedding logic inside the annotations as it's a bit harder to test; I'd prefer to use a bean or a custom `ReactiveAuthorizationManager`. I'd probably want to wait for a clearer use case where mixing the two types in a SpEL expression is better than one of these two alternatives. Just my 2c, though.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1083808290/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 2, 'created_at': '2022-03-24T08:28:12Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-30T23:09:21Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "Hello,

I was trying to extend the current pre authorization behavior to suit our needs. Basically I wanted to look at the request headers, if some conditions are met, execute a custom authorization code and grant access from that logic, otherwise delegate to default pre authorize authorization manager.

But this was very hard to understand and do.

In the documents, for customizing the @PreAuthorize authorization logic, it is said to be done like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159868373-717f9256-cae5-42bc-ad92-22be91be1d71.png)

But this only shows how to replicate the default behavior, not how to customize it.

As I set to do customize my logic and add a custom AuthorizationManager, I was faced with these challanges:

1. AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor doesn't have a factory function or constructor that just accepts an AuthorizationManager and can only be instantiated with a default authorization managers(Yes it has one that accepts an AuthorizationManager, but it also needs a pointcut, which I will come back later)
2. Since I saw that, I wanted to create a custom class that extended PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager. In here, I wanted to execute some logic or delegate to super in other cases. But I saw that PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager, or any other concrete implementation of AuthorizationManager, are marked as final and can't be extended to customize the logic and be provided to AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor.
3. Event if you write a custom AuthorizationManager that executes your logic or delegates to constructed PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager in other cases, you need to provide a Pointcut to pass to interceptor. Unfortunately, the utility class used to get the Pointcuts for @PreAuthorize annotation(AuthorizationMethodPointcuts) is package private and you can't easily create the pointcut that you need.

Because of that, I had to create a default AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor, get its Pointcut, than create my own custom interceptor with this pointcut and my custom delegating AuthorizationManger.

Here is the code that I had to write:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159869665-379325f2-ea9e-4636-b8c7-a0baa1c52e35.png)

And this is the custom AuthorizationManager:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159872621-2bd1983c-4b93-4aea-87e1-25dd5a561958.png)

The code is very small, but in order to get there, I had to fumble through a lot of source code.

There were a lot of pain points while trying to figure out how to do some basic thing.

Here our my suggestions:

1. Make the concrete implementations of AuthorizationManager non-final, so that we can extend them and customize it with our logic, or make them more composeable.
2. Add a builder or constructor to AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor to only get an AuthorizationManager to be used inside, and not bother with pointcuts and use the default one, as it is the case with factory function that takes a PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager.
3. Add a section on how to create your own AuthorizationManager and register it as default for one or more of the interceptors that come with @EnableMethodSecurity, ideally showing how to delegate to default managers.

I don't know if I over-complicated things with my limited knowledge of the new authorization architecture, but in other parts of the spring security, by just reading the source code and understanding the default behavior, I could extend or compose the existing classes with my own to suit my needs. But this was not that easy to do with the current authorization classes.

Thank you.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 1, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1083732938', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024#issuecomment-1083732938', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024', 'id': 1083732938, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOADAMs85AmHPK', 'user': {'login': 'jzheaux', 'id': 3627351, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjM2MjczNTE=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3627351?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jzheaux', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-30T23:09:20Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-30T23:09:20Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': 'In the meantime, I think I can simplify the code you have written. Have you already seen [this sample](https://docs.spring.io/spring-security/reference/servlet/authorization/method-security.html#jc-method-security-custom-authorization-manager) in the documentation (slightly altered for your situation):

```java
@Bean 
@Role(BeanDefinition.ROLE_INFRASTRUCTURE)
public Advisor preAuthorize(InternalPreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager rules) {
        AnnotationMethodMatcher pattern = new AnnotationMethodMatcher(PreAuthorize.class);
	AuthorizationManagerAfterMethodInterceptor interceptor = new AuthorizationManagerAfterMethodInterceptor(pattern, rules);
	interceptor.setOrder(AuthorizationInterceptorsOrder.PRE_AUTHORIZE.getOrder());
	return interceptor;
}
```

You can also take a look at [`AnnotationMatchingPointcut`](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/main/core/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/authorization/method/AuthorizationMethodPointcuts.java#L46) if you need more specialized sophisticated annotation searching behavior like class-level annotations or annotation inheritance.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1083732938/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2022-03-24T08:28:12Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-30T23:09:16Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "Hello,

I was trying to extend the current pre authorization behavior to suit our needs. Basically I wanted to look at the request headers, if some conditions are met, execute a custom authorization code and grant access from that logic, otherwise delegate to default pre authorize authorization manager.

But this was very hard to understand and do.

In the documents, for customizing the @PreAuthorize authorization logic, it is said to be done like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159868373-717f9256-cae5-42bc-ad92-22be91be1d71.png)

But this only shows how to replicate the default behavior, not how to customize it.

As I set to do customize my logic and add a custom AuthorizationManager, I was faced with these challanges:

1. AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor doesn't have a factory function or constructor that just accepts an AuthorizationManager and can only be instantiated with a default authorization managers(Yes it has one that accepts an AuthorizationManager, but it also needs a pointcut, which I will come back later)
2. Since I saw that, I wanted to create a custom class that extended PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager. In here, I wanted to execute some logic or delegate to super in other cases. But I saw that PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager, or any other concrete implementation of AuthorizationManager, are marked as final and can't be extended to customize the logic and be provided to AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor.
3. Event if you write a custom AuthorizationManager that executes your logic or delegates to constructed PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager in other cases, you need to provide a Pointcut to pass to interceptor. Unfortunately, the utility class used to get the Pointcuts for @PreAuthorize annotation(AuthorizationMethodPointcuts) is package private and you can't easily create the pointcut that you need.

Because of that, I had to create a default AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor, get its Pointcut, than create my own custom interceptor with this pointcut and my custom delegating AuthorizationManger.

Here is the code that I had to write:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159869665-379325f2-ea9e-4636-b8c7-a0baa1c52e35.png)

And this is the custom AuthorizationManager:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16986743/159872621-2bd1983c-4b93-4aea-87e1-25dd5a561958.png)

The code is very small, but in order to get there, I had to fumble through a lot of source code.

There were a lot of pain points while trying to figure out how to do some basic thing.

Here our my suggestions:

1. Make the concrete implementations of AuthorizationManager non-final, so that we can extend them and customize it with our logic, or make them more composeable.
2. Add a builder or constructor to AuthorizationManagerBeforeMethodInterceptor to only get an AuthorizationManager to be used inside, and not bother with pointcuts and use the default one, as it is the case with factory function that takes a PreAuthorizeAuthorizationManager.
3. Add a section on how to create your own AuthorizationManager and register it as default for one or more of the interceptors that come with @EnableMethodSecurity, ideally showing how to delegate to default managers.

I don't know if I over-complicated things with my limited knowledge of the new authorization architecture, but in other parts of the spring security, by just reading the source code and understanding the default behavior, I could extend or compose the existing classes with my own to suit my needs. But this was not that easy to do with the current authorization classes.

Thank you.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 1, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1083732825', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024#issuecomment-1083732825', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11024', 'id': 1083732825, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOADAMs85AmHNZ', 'user': {'login': 'jzheaux', 'id': 3627351, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjM2MjczNTE=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3627351?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jzheaux', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jzheaux/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-30T23:09:15Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-30T23:09:15Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': "Thanks for the analysis and suggestions, @fatihdogmus, I'm glad that you are trying out the new `AuthorizationManager` support. 

Given that the support is quite new, we anticipate enhancements being needed. That said, I'm a little confused about your usage of method security support, and I want to make sure I'm clear before we try and figure out how to change things. 

First, why are you trying to look at request headers during method invocation instead of in the filter chain? Second, do these headers affect both authentication and authorization? Maybe a sample request and its interpretation would help me understand better.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1083732825/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'2022-03-30T20:35:53Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Describe the bug**
Running SpringBoot version 2.6.3
Spring Security 5.6.1

Running 
` .addFilterBefore(new FireBaseTokenFilter(), FireBaseTokenFilter.class)` throws NullPointerException, getOrder is null

**To Reproduce**

WebSecurity Config File
```
@Configuration
@EnableWebSecurity
@EnableGlobalMethodSecurity(prePostEnabled = true)
public class WebSecurityConfig extends WebSecurityConfigurerAdapter {

    private static final String[] AUTH_WHITELIST = {"/api/verifyToken"};

    @Override
    protected void configure(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
        http
                .cors().and()
                .csrf().disable()
                .addFilterBefore(new FireBaseTokenFilter(), FireBaseTokenFilter.class)
                .sessionManagement().sessionCreationPolicy(STATELESS).and()
                .authorizeRequests()
                .antMatchers(AUTH_WHITELIST).permitAll()
                .anyRequest().authenticated();

        http.headers().frameOptions().disable();
    }
}
```

Custom Filter 
```
@Order(1)
@Component
public class FireBaseTokenFilter extends OncePerRequestFilter {

    @Override
    protected void doFilterInternal(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response, FilterChain chain) throws ServletException, IOException {
       //Filter Code Here
    }
}
```

**Expected behavior**
The filter should run

I read  #9787 and it seems like the bug was fixed?

This workaround seems to work
`
.addFilterBefore(new FireBaseTokenFilter(), SecurityContextHolderAwareRequestFilter.class)
`

Can anyone give any pointers? Appreciated

- added AuthorizationFailureEvent to represent event for denied AuthorizationDecision

- added DefaultAuthorizationEventPublisherTests to handle respective test scenarios

- updated DelegatingAuthorizationManager to add AuthorizationEventPublisher to raise authorization events
- updated DelegatingAuthorizationManagerTests to add respective test scenarios

Closes gh-10842', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/spring-security/commits/1762a4ce7015cbeb2cbbc59fe41fb3e372c2aeea'}, {'sha': '2abeff20894d5f579992b8b9009c219b5f8b7dc1', 'author': {'email': 'rwinch@users.noreply.github.com', 'name': 'Rob Winch'}, 'message': 'HttpSessionSecurityContextRepository saves with original response

Previously, the HttpSessionSecurityContextRepository unnecessarily required
the HttpServletResponse from the HttpReqeustResponseHolder passed into
loadContext. This meant code that wanted to save a SecurityContext had to
have a reference to the original HttpRequestResponseHolder. Often that
implied that the code that saves the SecurityContext must also load the
SecurityContext.

This change allows any request / response to be used to save the
SecurityContext which means any code can save the SecurityContext not just
the code that loaded it. This sets up the code to be permit requiring
explicit saves. Using the request/response from the
HttpRequestResponseHolder is only necessary for implicit saves.

Closes gh-10947', 'distinct': True, 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/jzheaux/spring-security/commits/2abeff20894d5f579992b8b9009c219b5f8b7dc1'}, {'sha': '5f37ee2f647a5494d656b266965d416391d3dea9', 'author': {'email': 'sriesenberg@vmware.com', 'name': 'Steve Riesenberg'}, 'message': 'Add missing output and checkout

'created_at': '2019-10-16T00:26:16Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-23T20:45:40Z', 'closed_at': '2022-03-23T20:45:40Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '### Summary

`AbstractUserDetailsReactiveAuthenticationManager` [invokes the `PasswordEncoder`](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/8ebfba3019e337543e954670373916d93496bed7/core/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/authentication/AbstractUserDetailsReactiveAuthenticationManager.java#L102-L113) in a [parallel Scheduler by default](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/8ebfba3019e337543e954670373916d93496bed7/core/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/authentication/AbstractUserDetailsReactiveAuthenticationManager.java#L58).

`PasswordEncoder` implementations (e.g. [BCryptPasswordEncoder](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/master/crypto/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/crypto/bcrypt/BCryptPasswordEncoder.java#L104)) will potentially block when generating random salt data using `SecureRandom`, since some `SecureRandom` implementations will block while reading entropy. 

I think the `AbstractUserDetailsReactiveAuthenticationManager` should execute this potentially blocking code on a Scheduler meant for blocking tasks (e.g.. `Schedulers.boundedElastic()` or `Schedulers.newBoundedElastic(...)`) to avoid blocking a parallel Scheduler.

BlockHound is reporting this blocking call as an illegal blocking call, since it executes on a parallel scheduler.

### Actual Behavior

`AbstractUserDetailsReactiveAuthenticationManager` invokes `PasswordEncoder.upgradeEncoding` on a parallel Scheduler by default, which causes BlockHound to report illegal blocking calls.

```
    at java.base/java.io.FileInputStream.readBytes(FileInputStream.java)
    at java.base/java.io.FileInputStream.read(FileInputStream.java:279)
    at java.base/java.io.FilterInputStream.read(FilterInputStream.java:133)
    at java.base/sun.security.provider.NativePRNG$RandomIO.readFully(NativePRNG.java:424)
    at java.base/sun.security.provider.NativePRNG$RandomIO.ensureBufferValid(NativePRNG.java:526)
    at java.base/sun.security.provider.NativePRNG$RandomIO.implNextBytes(NativePRNG.java:545)
    at java.base/sun.security.provider.NativePRNG.engineNextBytes(NativePRNG.java:220)
    at java.base/java.security.SecureRandom.nextBytes(SecureRandom.java:741)
    at org.springframework.security.crypto.bcrypt.BCrypt.gensalt(BCrypt.java:621)
    at org.springframework.security.crypto.bcrypt.BCrypt.gensalt(BCrypt.java:640)
    at org.springframework.security.crypto.bcrypt.BCrypt.gensalt(BCrypt.java:649)
    at org.springframework.security.crypto.bcrypt.BCryptPasswordEncoder.encode(BCryptPasswordEncoder.java:78)
    at org.springframework.security.crypto.password.DelegatingPasswordEncoder.encode(DelegatingPasswordEncoder.java:186)
    at org.springframework.security.authentication.UserDetailsRepositoryReactiveAuthenticationManager.lambda$authenticate$2(UserDetailsRepositoryReactiveAuthenticationManager.java:63)
```

### Expected Behavior

Blocking calls are not made on a parallel Scheduler.  BlockHound does not report illegal blocking calls.

### Configuration

Default spring boot configuration

### Version

5.2.0.RELEASE

'2019-12-16T10:37:29Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-23T20:41:50Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '<!--
For Security Vulnerabilities, please use https://pivotal.io/security#reporting
-->

### Summary
`<security:authentication-provider>` XML configuration element is missing a `user-details-password-service` child or attribute to set a `UserDetailsPasswordService` property 
<!-- 
Please provide a high level summary of the issue you are having
-->

### Actual Behavior
No means to set  UserDetailsPasswordService by XML configuration for `<security:authentication-provider>` and `DaoAuthenticationProvider` is missing a verification in `doAfterPropertiesSet` to check if `userDetailsService instanceof UserDetailsPasswordService` to set also `userDetailsPasswordService`  
<!-- 
Please describe step by step the behavior you are observing
-->

### Expected Behavior
Add an xml child element or an attribute in `<security:authentication-provider>`
<!--
Please describe step by step the behavior you expect
-->

### Configuration
```
<security:authentication-manager id="authenticationManager">
	<security:authentication-provider>
		<security:user-service data-source-ref="dataSource"/>
                 <security:password-encoder ref="delegatingPasswordEncoder"/>
                 <user-details-password-service ref="myUserDetailsPasswordService" />
	</security:authentication-provider>
</security:authentication-manager>
```

<!--
Please provide any configuration you have.
-->

### Version
spring-security-5.2.xsd
<!--
Please describe what version you are using. Does the problem occur in other versions?
-->

### Sample

<!--
Providing a complete sample (i.e. link to a github repository) will give this issue higher
priority than issues that do not have a complete sample
-->

+package org.springframework.security.authorization.method;
+
+import org.aopalliance.intercept.MethodInvocation;
+import reactor.core.publisher.Mono;
+
+import org.springframework.security.access.expression.method.MethodSecurityExpressionHandler;
+import org.springframework.security.access.prepost.PostAuthorize;
+import org.springframework.security.authorization.AuthorizationDecision;
+import org.springframework.security.authorization.ReactiveAuthorizationManager;
+import org.springframework.security.core.Authentication;
+
+/**
+ * A {@link ReactiveAuthorizationManager} which can determine if an {@link Authentication}
+ * has access to the returned object from the {@link MethodInvocation} by evaluating an
+ * expression from the {@link PostAuthorize} annotation.
+ *
+ * @author Evgeniy Cheban
+ */
+public final class PostAuthorizeReactiveAuthorizationManager
+		implements ReactiveAuthorizationManager<MethodInvocationResult> {
+
+	private final PostAuthorizeExpressionAttributeRegistry registry = new PostAuthorizeExpressionAttributeRegistry();
+
+	/**
+	 * Sets the {@link MethodSecurityExpressionHandler}.

'2022-03-17T21:35:27Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Describe the bug**
The `BasicAuthenticationFilter` skips re-authentication if the username changes in the basic authentication header and the `Authentication` object is not an instance of `UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken`.

The `BasicAuthenticationFilter` contains an `authenticationIsRequired` method that is private and so cannot be overridden to add handling for different Authentication object types that may support `UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken` style authentication, but do not inherit from the `UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken`.

We have an Authentication class that is a wrapper around existing authentication instances to allow us to provide MFA functionality after the Basic Authentication mechanism succeeds. 

**To Reproduce**

- Configure Spring Security with a custom authentication provider that wraps the `UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken` as a delegate. 
- Login with basic auth and maintain a session so the existing authentication is stored
- Send a second request for the same session with different basic auth credentials and the `authenticationIsRequired` check is skipped and you carry on with the original user auth. 

**Expected behaviour**
The `BasicAuthenticationFilter` should allow the `authenticationIsRequired` method to be overridden to allow additional checks for different `Authentication` types that support username/password but that cannot inherit from `UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken`, to allow this SEC-348 security check to be performed.

For security reasons we should not have to clone the `BasicAuthenticationFilter` to achieve this.

**Sample**

'This PR includes the following changes based on issue gh-7900

- `OidcClientInitiatedLogoutSuccessHandler` is now able to replace `{baseUrl}` and `{registrationId}` inside the redirect uri
- Adds a test to `OidcClientInitiatedLogoutSuccessHandlerTests` to verify the correct replace of the placeholders

Let me know if commit messages, test names, or something else can be wrong, i have also noticed that the Copyright and License dates are wrong in those classes should i fix them?

CLA already signed 

Issue gh-7900

- Moved methods so methods are listed before the methods they call
- Adjusted exception handling so no exceptions are eaten
- Adjusted so that malformed_request_data is returned with request data is malformed
- Refactored methods to have only immutable method parameters
- Removed usage of Stream API
- Moved AuthnRequestUnmarshaller into static block so that only looked
up once

'2022-03-15T20:05:05Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Describe the bug**
The InResponseTo field is not validated and the repsonse is not rejected when this does not correspond to a sent request.

**To Reproduce**
1. Set up SAML2 login and run your server locally which redirects to an IDP which will then redirect to an actual deployed SAML2 authentication endpoint.
2. Set the host of your deployed app to 127.0.0.1 in /etc/hosts
3. Ping the host and verify that localhost responds
4. Start the local app and try to log in, you will be directed to your IDP which will redirect back to the authentication endpoint which will not exist on your local machine, thereby resulting in a not found error.
5. Copy the unresponded request as cURL from the console and paste it in a document.
6. Add flags .L and -i and remove cookies headers to be on the safe side.
7. Remove the entry in /etc/hosts and verify that the actual deployed application responds on ping.
7. Run the command with cURL and verify that the deployed application authentication endpoint accepts the cURL command which is a response to a request NOT initiated by the deployed application but by the local application.

**Expected behavior**
If the request contains a InResponseTo which is incorrect, it should be rejected.

**Sample**

A link to a GitHub repository with a [minimal, reproducible sample](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example).

Reports that include a sample will take priority over reports that do not.
At times, we may require a sample, so it is good to try and include a sample up front.

'2022-03-13T13:13:06Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-15T19:16:12Z', 'closed_at': '2022-03-15T19:16:12Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'I have an application with following resources ,

- POST /car
- Create API POST /car/{someId}
- Update API GET /car/insurace
- POST /car/insurance-note - Required Basic AUTH

Only the last API needs basic auth , the rest above urls should allow everyone regardless if a "BASIC xxxx" . header is passed or not.

I have a configuration as follows,

```
http
                .antMatcher("/car/insurance-note")
                .httpBasic()
                .and().authorizeRequests().antMatchers("/car/**").permitAll();
```
This does allow access to other URLS regardless if I pass a BASIC header or not. However , it also allows the car/insurance note in without a BASIC header.

Then I changed the configuration to ,

```
http.authorizeRequests()
            .antMatchers("/car/insurance-note")
            .hasAuthority("USER")
            .and()
            .httpBasic()
            .and()
            .authorizeRequests()
            .antMatchers("/car/**")
            .permitAll();
```
Now , as well it looks like anytime a request has a "BASIC xxx" header the permit all does not work.

'color': 'e3d9fc', 'default': False, 'description': 'A general bug'}], 'state': 'closed', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2022-03-13T13:13:06Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-15T19:16:12Z', 'closed_at': '2022-03-15T19:16:12Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'I have an application with following resources ,

- POST /car
- Create API POST /car/{someId}
- Update API GET /car/insurace
- POST /car/insurance-note - Required Basic AUTH

Only the last API needs basic auth , the rest above urls should allow everyone regardless if a "BASIC xxxx" . header is passed or not.

I have a configuration as follows,

```
http
                .antMatcher("/car/insurance-note")
                .httpBasic()
                .and().authorizeRequests().antMatchers("/car/**").permitAll();
```
This does allow access to other URLS regardless if I pass a BASIC header or not. However , it also allows the car/insurance note in without a BASIC header.

Then I changed the configuration to ,

```
http.authorizeRequests()
            .antMatchers("/car/insurance-note")
            .hasAuthority("USER")
            .and()
            .httpBasic()
            .and()
            .authorizeRequests()
            .antMatchers("/car/**")
            .permitAll();
```
Now , as well it looks like anytime a request has a "BASIC xxx" header the permit all does not work.

'state': 'open', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 0, 'created_at': '2022-03-11T23:53:12Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-11T23:53:12Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "Making Spring Security's actions observable at runtime will help make applications more secure. Following [recommendations from OWASP](https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Logging_Cheat_Sheet.html#which-events-to-log), we should: 

- [ ] [Add authorization events](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/9527)
- [ ] Add OAuth2 client authorization events
- [ ] Add defense violation events
- [ ] Add user/password lifecycle events
- [ ] Consider introducing secure header `report-uri` endpoints

It would be helpful to have a marker class that security events can be identified by:

- [ ] Add SecurityEvent

When these events are fired, Spring Security should listen and then:

- [ ] Audit authentication events
- [ ] Audit authorization events
- [ ] Audit defense violation events
- [ ] Audit session management events 
- [ ] Audit security context events
- [ ] Audit custom security events

Auditing actions may include logging or counting.

It can also help applications evaluate performance and usage. To that end we should:

- [ ] Time `AuthenticationProvider` implementations
- [ ] Time `OAuth2AuthorizedClientProvider` implementations
", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10964/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10964/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}
